commits.commitMessage:
[Audio] Add NMMAP playback implementation

Issue Description:
    Currently, only NMMAP is supported for Kernel-4.14, but NMMAP playback is not implemented.

Resolves: LE-16343
Related: QTI9X07-5521
Change-Id: I2b96269142551f73830f7f58e4eabae1969f1fd0
Signed-off-by: Philip Yeh <pyeh@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: [Audio] Add NMMAP playback implementation

comments.message:
Could you please change the title in accordance with the commit message guideline:

"[Audio] Add NMMAP playback implementation" or
"[Audio] Support NMMAP playback"
or something like that.

https://confluence.sierrawireless.com/display/LEGATO/Write+Commit+Messages

Could you please re-arrange this sentence?

For example:
"Currently, only MMAP is supported for Kernel-4.14, but NMMAP playback is not implemented."

Hi Philip,

Thank you for the fix. I am not very familiar with audio, but this change looks okay to me. Please find a few suggestions in line.

Just that originally MMAP option for Tx and playback was introduced in https://issues.sierrawireless.com/browse/LE-5603 due to a quality issue in AR. That is an old ticket, but could you please ensure this issue is not present now?

Regards
Anju

Hi Anju,
Provide evidence PlayDtmf_first_wave_oscilloscope.jpg in LE-16343

Is this part of the code common to both MMAP and NMAP case? That is, in case of NMMAP if we do only
bufferPtr = data

Can we keep rest of the code outside the MMAP/NMMAP if-else?

Thank you for the changes and the test Philip. Please find a few suggestions in-line.

Regards
Anju
The readability might be better if we bring this definition near to bufferPtr and data below.
This check may not be needed, since, in case of MMAP we will anyway re-assign bufferPtr to dst_address(pcm).
Is this required for NMMAP? Doesn't pcm_write() take care of the pcm_prepare() for NMMAP case?
pcm_prepare() is checking sndrv pcm ready or not, need to be checked once no matter MMAP or NMMAP.
Is the formatting changed by mistake?

Looks good to me.

Regards
Anju

commits.commitMessage:
[AUDIO] Fix kernel issue with a Work-around on audio playback in wp76xx.

Issue Description:
The legato is hung after executing le_audio_PlayDtmf().

Root Cause:
MMAP cause kernel issue after calling le_audio_PlayDtmf().
Using of PCM_MMAP is causing kernel crash due to NULL pointer access.

Solution:
Replace PCM_NMMAP to disable the use of PCM_MMAP.
Will revert this work-around after QTI9X07-5410 fixed.
Difference between PCM_MMAP and PCM_NMMAP is
PCM_MMAP will map to memory but PCM_NMMAP will not.

Resolves: LE-16067
Related: QTI9X07-5410
Change-Id: I0284e0d265955b8a7d8fcda9e6e77c99b1720672
Signed-off-by: Gary Zeng <gzeng@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: [AUDIO] Fix kernel issue with a Work-around on audio playback in wp76xx.

comments.message: This seems more like a work-around rather than a fix. Can we get some more information on the impact of this change in commit message? What is the difference between PCM_MMAP and PCM_NMMAP?

I modified commit message.
Check please.

Please ensure that first word is an infinitive verb.
Eg.
[AUDIO] Do not request for PCM_MMAP

It will be good to bring a bit more clarity here:
Eg.
"Using of PCM_MMAP is causing kernel crash due to NULL pointer access."

It may be good to move the reference to QTI ticket as a "Related:" field in the commit message.

This needs rephrasing.
Eg.
"Replace PCM_NMMAP to disable the use of PCM_MMAP."

Also may be good to add:

"PCM_NMMAP stands for PCM no MMAP."
correction: "Replace with PCM_NMMAP to disable the use of PCM_MMAP."

Hi Gary,

Please find a few cosmetic comments around the commit message. The code change looks good to me, as a work-around.

Regards
Anju

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

maybe it is simpler to use msleep
```
calvin@cnhkg-ed-slqs01 ~/f/l/legato ❯❯❯ ack msleep platformAdaptor                                                                         remotes/m/master ✭ ◼
platformAdaptor/qmi/src/components/le_pa/pa_mdc_qapi.c
1261:        msleep(500);
```

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1
> 
> maybe it is simpler to use msleep
> ```
> calvin@cnhkg-ed-slqs01 ~/f/l/legato ❯❯❯ ack msleep platformAdaptor                                                                         remotes/m/master ✭ ◼
> platformAdaptor/qmi/src/components/le_pa/pa_mdc_qapi.c
> 1261:        msleep(500);
> ```

Please check what msleep() uses behind the scene. Sleep() is no good, since it's implemented with the use of SIGALRM.
Reference: LE-8202, via which the entire Legato code base was moved away from its use.
Another reference: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42861913/why-use-usleep-and-not-sleep

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> > Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1
> > 
> > maybe it is simpler to use msleep
> > ```
> > calvin@cnhkg-ed-slqs01 ~/f/l/legato ❯❯❯ ack msleep platformAdaptor                                                                         remotes/m/master ✭ ◼
> > platformAdaptor/qmi/src/components/le_pa/pa_mdc_qapi.c
> > 1261:        msleep(500);
> > ```
> 
> Please check what msleep() uses behind the scene. Sleep() is no good, since it's implemented with the use of SIGALRM.
> Reference: LE-8202, via which the entire Legato code base was moved away from its use.
> Another reference: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42861913/why-use-usleep-and-not-sleep

good point, thanks for sharing

Patch Set 1:

A feedback from an external email thread:

From: Libinesh Kumaran Thiya <Libinesh_Thiya@infosys.com> 
Sent: Wednesday, March 25, 2020 5:13 AM
To: Calvin Fong <cfong@sierrawireless.com>; Andrew Au <AnAu@sierrawireless.com>; Lawrence Wong <lwo@sierrawireless.com>; Gary Lei <gli@sierrawireless.com>
Cc: Justin Chow <JusChow@sierrawireless.com>; Eric Lok <elo@sierrawireless.com>; atdevelopment@infosys.com
Subject: RE: Change in ...audio[master]: Small part of an audio file at the end is not played.

Hi All,

We checked that msleep is uninterruptible but usleep or nanosleep is interruptible if a Signal arrives. For this case we think that we would not need an uninterruptible sleep.
In ‘~(root)/platformAdaptor/audio/qmi/src/components/le_pa_audio/pa_audio.c’ there were instances of usleep and hence we used this.
While usleep is supported, it has become obsolete and we can update the code to use nanosleep instead.
Please let us know your views.

Thanks,
Libinesh

Patch Set 1:

Another feedback from an external email thread:

From: Jerome Chassain <jchassain@sierrawireless.com> 
Sent: Wednesday, March 25, 2020 1:19 AM
To: Calvin Fong <cfong@sierrawireless.com>; Andrew Au <AnAu@sierrawireless.com>
Cc: Mehdi Allaoui <MAllaoui@sierrawireless.com>; Paul Burnard <PBU@sierrawireless.com>
Subject: RE: Change in ...audio[master]: Small part of an audio file at the end is not played.

Thanks Calvin,

+ Mehdi & Paul

Just a quick comment , 200ms silence is “understandable” for human ear, so it means if we play in loop a 70ms tone for example, we will have at least a 200ms delay between each sound (frequency will be around 4 time less). I don’t know if it is acceptable or not. 
I mean there is some fw update that are done through audio, and I’m pretty sure that 200ms could be a mess for them, but we are not in that situation for Doro.
Paul, could you please clarify what is this tone purpose on Doro’s application, and confirm the delay is acceptable for them ?

Best Regards
Jerome

commits.commitMessage:
Small part of an audio file at the end is not played.

It was observed that a very small tone at the end of a file
was not played. This was because the audio path was closed
prior to the end of stream.
Adding a delay of 200 ms before PCM is closed resolved the
issue and the tone could be heard.

Resolves: LE-14564
Change-Id: I1d7cf4e8429c454b6e72b93e2093a2738532d0df
Signed-off-by: infosys_ATMAINT <infosys_atmaint@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: Small part of an audio file at the end is not played.

comments.message:
To my understanding, usleep() shares the issue with sleep() that is implemented with the SIGALRM signal which can introduce bugs. For this reason, all the sleep() calls were replaced by le_thread_Sleep() in LE-8202. This le_thread_Sleep() is a wrapper that uses nanosleep() as it will not have this issue.

I would suggest using nanosleep() instead.

Abandoned

Oops, didn't meant to push on this branch.

commits.commitMessage:
Fix underrun issue in audio when play file

When underrun issue occurs, call pcm_prepare() to change device
to prepare state, and set pcm->start = 0, which will trigger driver
 read data from device.

Resolves: LE-12378
Related: LEAR7M-586
Change-Id: I71182c3c76f0a7671abd5fbc680f5da7e932b4ec
Signed-off-by: Emma Wang <ewang@sierrawireless.com>
Signed-off-by: Vincent Chen <vchen@sierrawireless.com>
Signed-off-by: Bertrand Roussel <broussel@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: Fix underrun issue in audio when play file

commits.commitMessage:
Fix underrun issue in audio when play file

When underrun issue occurs, call pcm_prepare() to change device
to prepare state, and set pcm->start = 0, which will trigger driver
 read data from device.

Resolves: LE-12378
Related: LEAR7M-586
Change-Id: I61c1f4aa6c943352b86b4086baa87aca65df7534

commits.commitMessage:
[Audio] Change the poll timeout value from TIMEOUT_INFINITE to 10s

After 10s it can return error, this is to avoid audio thread be
blocked forever due to driver issue, customer can't get the
LE_AUDIO_MEDIA_ENDED

Resolves: LE-12697
Related: LEAR7M-622
Change-Id: I80609e0ae96d8315185334acc218fa70772a9a09
Signed-off-by: Emma Wang <ewang@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: [Audio] Change the poll timeout value from TIMEOUT_INFINITE to 10s

commits.commitMessage:
Do not free hardware and software parameters data owned by ALSA

The data structures for hardware and software parameters are freed at
the end of the functions where they were created: those data must not
be freed by Legato because they are owned by ALSA once they are
successfully passed to the kernel through param_set_sw_params() and
param_set_hw_params(). At that stage, the data structure will be
automatically freed by ALSA at the end of the use-case when calling
pcm_close().
This patch fixes the regression introduced by manually freeing the
audio data parameters.

Resolves: LE-8288 LE-8291
Related: LE-8129
Change-Id: I7a7ce9bd0860cbe206837e92aaf74f6d108c89bb
commits.subject: Do not free hardware and software parameters data owned by ALSA

comments.message: Mixing uppercase and lowercase in the title ? I find it ugly :-)
ALSA is an acronym, I think it should be uppercase. But as you wish
Add a comment explaining why we should not free the parameters here, otherwise someone might revert it later
Add a comment explaining why we should not free the parameters here, otherwise someone might revert it later

Sonar [BLOCKER c:S3584]

> Review the data-flow - memory allocated at line 96 might have not been released.

Sonar [BLOCKER c:S3584]

> Review the data-flow - memory allocated at line 161 might have not been released.

As stated in the comment above, memory allocated at line 96 and 161 must not be released since it is own by ALSA at this point.
In this specific case, this SONAR issue is bogus.

Sonar [BLOCKER c:S3584]

> Review the data-flow - memory allocated at line 276 might have not been released.

Sonar [BLOCKER c:S3584]

> Review the data-flow - memory allocated at line 212 might have not been released.

As stated in the comment above, memory allocated at line 212 and 276 must not be released since it is own by ALSA at this point.
In this specific case, this SONAR issue is bogus.

commits.commitMessage:
Prevent audio playback busy loop when all samples have been read

When there are no more samples to be played during a PlaySamples
procedure, the playback thread continues looping without writing any
data to the ALSA driver: this behaviour basically amounts to a busy
loop, therefore causing a CPU overload.
This patch prevents the playback busy loop when all samples have been
read.

Resolves: LE-7207 LE-6713
Change-Id: Ifdcc13bad9d0d11807b6198593fbf6b975c4077e
commits.subject: Prevent audio playback busy loop when all samples have been read

comments.message: This is just some cleanup that was long overdue (POLLERR event only makes sense when checking revents).
This is just some cleanup that was long overdue.

No, we should contextualize this variable if it is in static.

BTW, why is it is static ?

I think this is not clear, as it is set in the thread, it would be always set to true.
Maybe playbackRunning ? stateRunning ?

@Tristan: "Then why do you submit another patch on the master ? I suppose it will be automatically ported from the 16-07stabel branch once it will be merged."

I did not know that porting a patch from 16-07 to master is an "automatic" process (which is good news).
However, in this case there is a git conflict when cheery-picking the patch from 16-07 because of a difference in the code base, which is why I re-submitted the patch myself on master.

I'll check on the correct way to do this.

commits.commitMessage:
Reduce cpu usage during playback

PCM playback relies on the poll system call to wait until audio frames
can be written to the pcm playback device.
Polling was done on the read-only timer_fd file descriptor thus
inducing high cpu usage in the write loop.

This issue is fixed by polling the pcm playback device main file
descriptor instead of the read-only timer_fd descriptor.

Resolves: LE-6395
Change-Id: I9e8d317126bc0594c02dc1276380b68c7abffdec
commits.subject: Reduce cpu usage during playback

comments.message:
Sonar [MAJOR c:S874]

> Do not apply "&" bitwise operator to a signed operand.

This issue looks bogus to me : for bitwise '&' operand the C standard states that "Each of the operands shall have integer type", so the sign is irrelevant at the bitwise level (chapter 6.5.10: http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg14/www/docs/n1570.pdf).

Will check how to instruct Sonar to ignore this false positive.
Agree to use LE_IO_ERROR, but how this return code is handled by caller ?

I suspect the issue reported on AR758x DV2 is an underrun, but how this error is handled will depend on the analysis of this issue (continuing the loop to re-call pcm_prepare() does not seem to be ennough, analysis on-going).

comments.message: Could you describe the role of each member?
Could you add a short description of the algorithm here?

pcm->running is set to 1 and to 0. But, on some error cases, it stays to 1.
For me, this is not clear when it could be reset to 0 before exiting...

I tried to simply the function.
When errno==EPIPE, we try to start again (it may be an "expected" error)
Otherwise, the function returns LE_FAULT. In all case, le_media will stop the playback calling pa_pcm_Close().
May be a #define PCM_THREAD_NAME_LEN instead of a value.
I prefer see: snprintf( threadName, sizeof(threadName),...);
Perhaps, a pcm->running = 0 may be missing ?

No, I don't think so... the playback of the file is over, but the alsa driver is not closed, and it is still possible to send PCM frames (playsamples use case). It will be not running when pcm_close will be called
you should return an error, the should you release alsaIntfPtr ?
If I release alsaIntfPtr, I can't try to stop the alsa again. So I prefer not release it.
